awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Trustable Computing Systems Security Research and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This funding establishes a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the University of Connecticut focused on computer systems security research. Students will participate in research projects that should advance computer security and trustable computing hardware research. Specific activities include collaborative projects in the Electrical and Computer Engineering Department and Computer Science and Engineering Department, including research in hardware support for computer security, hardware Trojan detection, and IC authentication.   A series of training seminars will equip students with knowledge specific to the various research projects as well as general skills required in graduate school. In addition, participants will have the opportunity to participate in the Hardware-Oriented Security and Trust Symposium. This will broaden students' vision by allowing them to witness research projects conducted worldwide. This site is co-funded by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program. 

Intellectual merit: The intellectual merit of this project lies with the strong research team and the focus on computer systems security, an area of national need and of interest to students. The students will participate in research initiatives that investigate algorithmic techniques, hardware and software design principles, computer architecture, and other aspects of trustable computing systems. A major goal of this project is to introduce such interdisciplinary research work to students in the early stages of their academic careers to spark their interests. At the same time, the research has the potential to contribute to the research core of the computing disciplines.

Broader impacts: This project is aimed at preparing undergraduate students for graduate study in a research area of vital national interest. Computer systems are integrated into every part of our national infrastructure - including financial systems, communication systems, transportation, and defense. A primary national need is research and researchers who can address the security of these systems. The research opportunities that this proposal provides will help develop the next generation of researchers investigating these important computer security issues.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this project was to give undergraduate students research opportunities in the area of computer systems security. The primary outcome has been to introduce trustable computing systems research work to undergraduate students in the early stages of their academic careers and spark their interest in pursuing graduate students. In addition, the program prepared students to formalize and solve hardware computer systems security issues.  Over the 3 years of the project, we enabled 27 students to experience systems security research first hand - over half of whom were from universities without research programs, and a third were underrepresented minorities.

Student researchers attended a variety of seminars on professional topics (writing, presentations, graduate school).  They also made presentations on their research projects throughout the program including at a summer-ending symposium held in conjunction with other research programs on campus.  A highlight of the program was a trip to the Hardware Oriented Security and Trust Symposium in June 2011, 2012, and 2013. All participants were given an introductory seminar by graduate students and faculty to prepare them for the symposium. At the symposium, the REU participants were accompanied by a graduate student who led discussions about the papers presented at the symposium. After the symposium, the REU students had the opportunity to attend the Design Automation Conference exhibit floor and see the various companies in the EDA field.
